column2: kathi, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: upset stinacg

column2: lawnbrundle, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have been taking Bentyl for years for esophageal spasms or "nutcracker esophagus". The name sounds painful and believe me it is!! I am able to take it only when I feel an episode coming on. Each episode can last from minutes to hours. I also have learned to avoid some triggers like granny smith apples and Wheaties.  Weird? yes I know.  It took months to sort out the diagnosis because my gall bladder was coinidentally bad at the same time. Got rid of that, had a "swallow study" and ruled out heart attacks.  Tried several other drugs that were not effective in controling the spasming. Bentyl is a lifesaver for me.  It works by relaxing the smooth muscles.  This is also why it works for irritable bowel and spastic colon. Makes me sort of drowsy but I can still function normally.  Dry mouth is very minimal and I usually do get a headache, usually when the med is wearing off.  Its not bad or bothersome enough to make me not take Bentyl however.  Within a few hours the headache is usually gone as is the other symptoms.  The longer you take it, the softer the side effects as your body gets used to them.Its funny how a drug made for a specific syndrome (irritable bowel) can be used in other ways and be just as effective!

column2: Suz, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I've had IBS for 40 years and am 65. It stops my colon from being spastic. It took this long to find a doctor who knew what to give me for the cramping.  The spasms were debilitating, so I will be eternally grateful for this drug!

column2: wrm1958, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Great drug,  helps alot

column2: Wonderful100, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have had IBS for years. About 3 years ago I had a colonscopy and was diagnosed with collegeous colitis. The pain was in my right lower abdomen elevating up to the gall bladder area. The doctor did a CT Scan and nothing was found. It even hurts when I put pressure on my right leg. So a C-Reactive Protein test is being done (with no results yet). It helps but now I have started having the shakes and I don't like it. But what am I to do. Also taking Bentyl (generic) along with my other meds, I really feel bombed out. I tske it 3 times a day before meals. Since I have started taking the Bentyl, it has helped the pain. After so long, the med wears off and I start having the pains again. It is helping but I pray I don't have to stay on it the rest of my life. BM is more firm that before since starting Bentyl.

Blurry vision, hard time concentrating, and feeling a bit out of it.  Does anyone know whether these side effects go away over time?  Is this something that your body needs to get adjusted to or if you have these side effects will you always have them.  Although the side effects are bad and it is very hard to work will feeling the side effects I am still willing to use this drug as it is unbelievably helpful.  Please let me know if these side effects eventually went away for anyone else.

column2: Angela, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I was diagnosed with ulceractive colitis in 2001 and was prescribed bentyl and although it has helped with the pain it has also caused other problems to. It is now 11-7-10 and I was taken off it 3 weeks ago. I started having extreme pain in my stomach and was constantly vomiting in march of 2010. I was refered to the mayo clinic and was diagnosed with Barret's esophogus and Gastro-paresis along with IBS. (Oh and just a note on IBS It is diagnosed so no more test will be ordered. There is no such thing as IBS. Its a diagnoses when the physician can't tell u whats really wrong.) I am very sick and my stomach is dying. I believe that the bentyl has caused me more problems than not. I can't prove it but I was on this medication for almost 9yrs. It was the greatest drug when I began taking it in 2001 but I remained on it for so long that it has caused me so many more problems. For short term use its a great medication, but I WOULD NOT recommend it for a long period of time. Also, there is a new drug called Kapidex, its very expensive, but its worth it. It has helped me so much. For all the people out there with stomach problems, my prayers and thoughts r with you.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I take 10mg anywhere from 1-3 times per day as needed for IBS.  It does little to ease my abdominal pain, that I can tell. The worst has definitely been the side effects. I am VERY sensitive to medications and experience unpleasant side effects with nearly any medication, and bentyl has been no different. My worst reactions, which occur even when I have been off it for several days and only take one pill, I have very unpleasant mental feelings (like paranoia and mild delusions), and blurred vision (to the point where I can no longer drive myself and cannot function in my classes, since I often can't even see the blackboard or projection screen!).  My vision can't be corrected for this, since the degree of blurriness changes from day to day. Less problematic but still annoying is that it gives me very dry mouth.  It also used to make me tired, but no so much anymore.I'm sure this medication has probably helped a lot of people, but it hasn't worked for me.  My doctors are aware of all of the problems I've had, but none of them seem to care enough to do anything about it or change my medication.  I am getting off of this as soon as I can.

column2: mdmfc1, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been taking Bentyl for about 3 months.  It works great.  At first I only took it when needed.  And it really helped almost immediately. But the dry eyes is a small price to pay for relief.

column2: pheephee, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I use as needed when I have a flare-up.  I avoid the foods that bother me: milk products, yellow/red onions, onion or garlic salts or powders.  Now if restaurant workers would REALLY read the labels! I am a 6 year survivor of Stage IV colon cancer, and I do need people to be careful what they tell me is in the food.  This flare-up is from them sprinkling some powdered junk on the pollo asada I ordered; it is usually marinated in natural ingredients, and I can eat it.  Just messed my clothes at the store because it is not for diarrhea, but to slow the peristaltic action of the whole digestive tract in order to reduce cramping.  Overall, it has been useful and effective.  And I do not need it very often.  I also use digestive enzymes (omnigest or other)when I eat out, probiotics or liquid acidophylus after flare-ups, and watch what I eat.  I also eat sitting, and I do not get up to get anything once I start to eat.  I also use medical hypnosis to ease stress so I have fewer flare-ups. I was first diagnosed with IBS at age 31.

column2: 65-74 Female  (Patient)
column9: Very fast acting. Received immediate relief.

column2: shannonvirgo, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have been on this medication for many years now. I have IBS and sometimes get HORRIBLE stomach pains! I am to take this 3 times a day but I usually take it 2 times. The only side effect I have is it makes me a little tired. I see that many people are saying that it did not help their diarrhea, it is not for that. If you have bad diarrhea you should also take Lomotil.  With IBS you have both constipation and diarrhea. Bentyl is just to control the pain that comes with IBS.  When diarrhea acts up you need to take something seperate to treat that. Like I said Lomotil works well for that.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)

column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I've struggled with IBS for most of my life, and during middle school, my doctor gave me Bentyl to take for relief.  The first time I tried it, it worked immediately, and I ended up taking it every day for about four years.  Now I only take it once or twice every few months, as I've learned to cope with the IBS better, Bentyl helped in that regard.  I'm not sure if it was legitimate in treating the IBS or if it was simply a placebo, but either way it was a security blanket that helped me gain some control of my life back.  I still struggle with IBS, and still take Bentyl.  It isn't a guaranteed cure or treatment, but 9 times out of 10 it will help reduce IBS symptoms and at least increase my ability to cope.

column2: JessiLynn, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)

My doc prescribed me Bentyl and it did NOT work for me. I called her a week later and she switched my meds. I am now (come to find out, which I was NOT told up front) on an antidepressant which also serves as a muscles relaxant. It has helped relax my stomach cramps, but the symptoms are still there otherwise. I have both the "go" and the "not go" problem back and forth. I am getting a referral to a GI - any other suggestions? I'm really tired of the discomfort and a few days later having to run to bathroom. Not the ideal lifestyle of a college student!
